A new system regulating the clerk
proposition in County Auditor Hans
Anderson's Office and in the office OF
County Treasurer Don Mcdonald will
be inaugurated on April / according
to a recent ruling of the board of
county commissioners.


Formerly there have been three
clerks in the county auditors office
and three in Treasurer McDonalds
office. Between November / and April
l the help in the treasurer's Office is
worked overtime keeping track of the
taxes which roll into the Office but
after the latter date the work eases
on and the county auditor and his
deputies get their share of the hard
ship.


Under the new system one clerk
will be kept moving between the two
offices so as to relieve the rush of
work during the respective busy sea-
sons.

a detachment of the United States Signal
Corps made a successful flight Saturday
afternoon. stated in The Star, leaving
the vicinity of the Washington Gaslight
Company's plant in the southeast section
OF the city about noon. and landing at Har-
mons. Md, few miles this side of Bal

the trip were Capt. C. Def. Chandler. U. 8.
8. c.. and ]. c. Mccoy. pilot of the New
York Aero Club, and prominent aero
naut. They were also in charge of the bal
loon. which made the successful flight from
this city to Harrisburg. Pa. last June.


According to both Capt Chandler and Mr..
Mccoy the trip made Saturday was sue
cessful in almost every respect They met
with decidedly unfavorable winds at first,
and their early flight was some what ham,
pered. but as they drifted toward Balt-
more, along the western shore of the upper
part of the Chesapeake bay the wind i'm
proved, and the big aerial ship made rapid
progress. Capt Chandler had decided upon
no particular destination when he started,
and as he found the balloon approaching the
Patapsco river leading into the bay. he de-
cided to call a halt. not being anxious to
caused the balloon to make It's descent.
landing in an open field short distance
from Harmons. which is small station on
the Pennsylvania railroad.


Although the speed made was by no
means as good as was registered on the
previous trip to Harrisburg. the flight was
made at higher altitude. Mr.. Mccoy. who
did the plotting. said the average height
was 1000 feet and the maximum height
1900 feet. Despite it's distance from the
earth the little speck in the skies caused
much interest among the country people
over whom it passed, and hundred Gu
rious and Interested persons were on hand
to greet the two aeronauts when they came
to anchor.


Nothing exciting or unusual occurred, and
when seen at the Willard Hotel after their
return to W aShington by train the aero
nauts were very enthusiastic over the trip
and the possibilities of balloon service in
war times. The big airship was brought to
Washington by rail.


The experiment with this balloon Is an
other instance Of 'in time of peace prepare
for war" Capt. Chandler is in command
of detachment Of the Signal Corps which
he is instructing in the art of ballooning.
with view of the permanent adoption of
balloon branch for this corps of the
army. There are ten soldiers in this detach
ment and they are as enthusiastic and in
terested in the work as is the captain HIM
self. The men are what might be called
novices in the art, but they are learning
rapidly and hand every day to be
instructed They have never made any real
trips" in the air as yet, but they will
within the next few weeks. They did the
work of filling the bag Of the balloon yes
the builder of the balloon. having every
thing in shipshape order for the ascension
ir an hour and half.


You can look for balloon flying through
the air high above Washington almost any
day now.

forty-five days in solid work. 1t

of foolishness that is so frequently
characteristic of legislatures. In
these days men are not sent to the
Legislature to have good time or to
spend their time frivolously. They
are sent there to think and work.
There are several great problems be

time and It is expected of the legis-
lature that it will solve most of
them. That body can not do so by
Willing It's time away foolishly and
in pickering: The oficiate of the
Legislature can largely prevent such
conduct on the part of the members.
II it but holds them down strictly to
business and a decorum that will do
credit to any State legislature.

ncuncement of the engagement OF
Miss Gladys Vanderbilt to Count
Laszlo Szechensi OF Budapest is made
In the Herald The Herald states that
the announcement is authorized No
date has been set for the wedding,
but 1t is expected that it will take
place at the Breakers, the Vanderbilt
mansion In Newport, some time this
autumn. The count, who is the young
est son of the late Count Emerich
Szechenyi, for some years ambassa-
dor from Austria-Hungary to Ger
many, is now in Newport, having ar
rived from Europe Tuesday night. He
is twenty-eight years old, rich and
good looking, has an hereditary seat
In the Hungarian parliament and is
one Of the chamberlains of the Aus
trian emperor.


Announcement of the engagement
will be received with great interest
both here and in Europe, owing to the
prominence of both families. Miss
Vanderbilt inherited from her father,
the late Cornelius Vanderbilt, for
tune of more than $10,000000. She
came into possession of this inherit
ance on attaining her majority last
August.


Miss Vanderbilt is the youngest
child of the late Cornelius and Mrs.
Vanderbilt and was introduced to New

of their own. Among the representa-
tives of that profession who appeared
before the house medical committee
Saturday were Drs. Carlisle of Sioux
Falls, Wilson of Miller. Palmer of
Madison, and Mccartney of Mitchell.
Carlisle is pushing a bill for reduc-
zion of the qualifications required in
passing a dental examination. He
claims that the present state board Of
examiners have formed a close trust
and will not let in dentists except on
regulations which debar most of them.
The other side accuses him of attempt
ing to run an office with cheap help st
Sioux Falls and desiring to get in men
who cannot pass in other states, and
the war Is on.

official of the United States govern
ment, charged with robbing the post
Office at Jamison some time ago.
Only a few weeks ago Robinson was
arrested on the charge Of completely
in the robbing of a store in Branch
Vile and he was bound over to court
on this charge. He was out on bond
when arrested for the postoffice rob-
berry. Hey carried to Orangeburg
and placed in Jail.


What the evidence against Robin.
son is we do not know, but we feel
sure he is not guilty of either charge,
for he has not been away from home.
His father lives on Mr.. N. 2. Felder's
place Just out of town, and Robinson
has been at home all winter. It is
really astonishing what flimsy evi-
dence negroes are arrested on only
too often.
